Quote: I live on a houseboat on the river Thames in Chelsea. The river is my daily companion, it's the center of my life. I go up and down on its tides, 20 feet twice a day, I go to sleep with the rocking of the tides. I have the birds of the river around me, incredible wildlife, beautiful light. It sings to me.

I went skinny-dipping in the River Dart with a bunch of other authors, all drunk after a big night at the Dartington book festival. It was a moonless night, pitch black and, as it’s a fast-flowing river, quite a dangerous thing to do. The collective stupidity of people who were all clever enough to have written books but still thought it a good idea gives me a small smile to this day. I won’t name names but there were some fairly famous individuals among the silvery forms in that dark, reed-filled water. I’m glad we all made it out.
I honestly hate rivers. They hide things. They disturb me and they frighten me.

There are two contenders. I once went on a school rafting trip down the Connecticut river, very wide and long, and I have deeply fond memories of that. The other is the Hudson, also wide and long. I have travelled by train down alongside it so often, I know its banks and its birds well.
